qas.question: A definition of literature that incorporates style and the poetic nature of prose is what?
What is one example of writing that the formalist definition distinguishes literature from?
What element of the formalist definition makes it difficult to apply?
What part of ordinary language makes it difficult to apply the formalist definition?

answers.text: an unstable category, differing according to social categories and across history

qas.question: The formalist definition when applied to industry writing allows it to be called literature when it does what?

answers.text: must use language according to particular standards

qas.question: What does the normalist definition of "literature" say distinguishes it from ordinary speech?
The term referring to unpublished material in a particular field includes what type of literature as one example?
Tim Meyer says scientific literature, for example, must use what?
Ordinary language is an unstable category that is the same according to what?

plausible_answers.text: in order to say that literature deviates from ordinary uses of language, those uses must first be identified;

qas.question: What is the problem Jim Meyer states with the formalist definition?

plausible_answers.text: it is the "literariness" or "poeticity" of literature that distinguishes it from ordinary speech or other kinds of writing

qas.question: What does the formalistic definition of literature state?
What is one type of writing not included in the formalistic definition of literature?
What is the difficulty with "ordinary language" according to cultural categories?
What is an example of unpublished material in a certain field?

plausible_answers.text: it is the "literariness" or "poeticity" of literature that distinguishes it from ordinary speech or other kinds of writing

qas.question: What is the formalist definition of history?
Jim Meyer considers what term to be useful in explaining scientific literature?
What is "ordinary language" considered according to social history and differing categories?

context: The <a0_0><b15_0>formalist<b15_0/><a0_0/> definition is that the history of "literature" foregrounds poetic effects; <b10_0><b14_0>it is the <b5_0>"literariness" or "poeticity" of literature<b5_0/> that distinguishes it from ordinary speech or other kinds of writing<b14_0/><b10_0/> (e.g., <a1_0><b11_0>journalism<b11_0/><a1_0/>). Jim Meyer considers this a useful characteristic in explaining the use of the term to mean published material in a particular field (e.g., "<b6_0><b13_0>scientific literature<b13_0/><b6_0/>"), as such writing <a4_0>must use <b7_0>language according to particular standards<b7_0/><a4_0/>. The problem with the formalist definition is that <b9_0>in order to say that literature deviates from ordinary uses of language, those uses must first be identified;<b9_0/> this is difficult because <a2_0>"ordinary language"<a2_0/> <b12_0>is <a3_0>an <b16_0>unstable category<b16_0/><b12_0/>, differing according to <b8_0>social categories<b8_0/> and across history<a3_0/>.
